review.title: Implicit Contextual Integrity in Online Social Networks
review.abstract: Many real incidents demonstrate that users of Online Social Networks need mechanisms that help them manage their interactions by increasing the awareness of the different contexts that coexist in Online Social Networks and preventing them from exchanging inappropriate information in those contexts or disseminating sensitive information from some contexts to others. Contextual integrity is a privacy theory that conceptualises the appropriateness of information sharing based on the contexts in which this information is to be shared. Computational models of Contextual Integrity assume the existence of well-defined contexts, in which individuals enact pre-defined roles and information sharing is governed by an explicit set of norms. However, contexts in Online Social Networks are known to be implicit, unknown a priori and ever changing; users relationships are constantly evolving; and the information sharing norms are implicit. This makes current Contextual Integrity models not suitable for Online Social Networks.

metadata.title: Implicit Contextual Integrity in Online Social Networks

sections.text: Many real-world incidents show that users of online social networks need mechanisms to help them manage their interactions by raising awareness of the different contexts that coexist in online social networks and preventing them from exchanging inappropriate information in those contexts or passing sensitive information from some contexts to others. Contextual integrity is a privacy theory that conceptualizes the appropriateness of information exchange based on the contexts in which that information is to be shared. Computer models of contextual integrity assume the existence of well-defined contexts in which individuals "predefined roles and information sharing are governed by an explicit set of norms. However, contexts in online social networks are known as implicit, unknown a priori and constantly changing; user relationships are constantly evolving; and the norms for information exchange are implicit. Thus, current models of contextual integrity online networks are referred to as the implicit information, and we propose the implicit information as the implicit contextual integrity model for this paper, not the contextual integrity model for this paper.

sections.heading: 2. Problem Statement
sections.text: IAAs aim to avoid two major threats to privacy in OSNs: the sharing of inappropriate information and the unwanted dissemination of previously exchanged information. In particular, they warn their users that sharing some information can lead to some of these threats. Next, we will describe these threats in more detail.

sections.heading: 2.1. Inappropriate Information Exchanges
sections.text: Each context has its own adequacy norms that determine what information can be mentioned within each context. For example, one may not mention their political views in a work context, but it can do so in a family context. IAAs use the information that their users share with other users in a context to derive from that the adequacy norms of that context. In particular, the information that is often mentioned by members of a work context is considered appropriate, while information that is never or rarely mentioned is considered inappropriate. For example, if most people do not mention their political views at work, it might be concluded that this is not a suitable topic for sharing in a work context. In addition to the adequacy norms of each context, there are situations where people decide to exchange information that may be considered inappropriate. One of the main reasons for this is the creation and reciprocity of close relationships [34]. In fact, there are empirical studies that show that mutual communication is the dominant form of interaction in SNs.

sections.heading: 2.2. Undesired Information Disseminations
sections.text: Disseminations occur when information disclosed in one context is placed in a different context; that is, disseminations are context-based disclosures, while exchanges (as mentioned above) are context-based disclosures. Obviously, disclosure of this information in these contexts cannot entail a new privacy risk if the information to be disclosed is already known in the context in which it could be disclosed. [68] Indeed, studies of remorse related to users "posts on OSN underscore the fact that disclosure of others" secrets is one of the main sources of regret [79]. Thus, there has recently been a case in which a person's sexuality leaked from their context with friends in their family context, where their sexuality was previously unknown, leading to them being outed and faced with threats to separate family relationships. [30] A primary defense against unwanted disseminations may consist of avoiding sensitive information in contexts in which people may live with their sexuality previously unknown to them.

sections.heading: 3. Information Model for Implicit Contextual Integrity
sections.text: In this section, we describe the implicit contextual integrity information model used by an IAA (further detailed in Section 4) to assist its user in obtaining information in the OSN.The information model considers a group of users U = {α, u1,..., un} who are members of an OSN and communicate in an OSN. Information exchanged between users is formalized as messages designated by tuples < g, R, T, S >; where g-U is the sender, R-U is the group formed by the recipient users, and T and S represent the information sent. Generally, messages represent any information exchange in an OSN that may be photos, comments, private messages, etc. Let's let T = {t1,..., tm} be a group of key topics or categories that can be discussed in messages.

sections.heading: 3.2. Information Dissemination
sections.text: Disseminations occur when the information exchanged in a context is leaked in contexts where that information is unknown. Therefore, it is critical to enable IAAs with the capabilities to anticipate the dissemination before it occurs. We suggest that IAAs use the messages sent and received in which users are explicitly tagged (e.g. by tagging them in a photo) to calculate the knowledge of associations between users and topics (e.g. the relationship between Bob and the topic of homosexuality) and determine which of them are unknown. Again, we start with the definition of individual knowledge values, then we define context values and finally define knowledge of messaging systems.

sections.heading: 4. Information Assistant Agent model
sections.text: Figure 1 shows the various modules that make up an IAA. We see that it aims to be placed between a user and an OSN2. Thus, an IAA is responsible for managing the interactions (i.e. messages sent and received) of an individual user in an OSN. An IAA could be implemented on an OSN infrastructure (or a social networking service) as a social networking app running on a trusted server, or it could be implemented as a local social app that acts as a proxy for accessing the OSN (i.e. a mobile social app). Also, note that an IAA does not store messages sent / received by its users, which helps to minimize the storage space for the information model, which may be important to implement an IAA as a local app for resource-limited devices such as smartphones. Also, note that IAAs use information that is currently being read by users in the mainstream tweets, and the relationships of their applications (i.e.).

sections.heading: 4.1. Community Finding Algorithm
sections.text: In OSNs, the people belonging to a particular context are commonly referred to as a community [32]. These communities [32] are natural subdivisions of net users into tightly connected subgroups. Many OSNs support a particular notion of community by allowing user groups (e.g. Facebook groups or Google + circles). There are even methods and ready-to-use tools that automatically obtain them through unattended machine learning algorithms [62]. For example, IAAs could use existing community-finding algorithms to extract the different communities, such as Infomap [62], which is known to work accurately in OSNs like Facebook [26] and is the algorithm that IAAs use for the examples and evaluations we perform, as described later in the paper. Note that OSN infrastructures only allow each user a partial view of the OSN (which includes his friends and mutual friends).

sections.heading: 5. Illustrative Examples
sections.text: This section illustrates the performance of the IAA using some representative examples. In particular, these examples are intended to demonstrate IAAs "ability to: (i) manage evolving user relationships, (ii) dynamic contexts, and (iii) distinguish between unusual and inappropriate information.

sections.heading: 5.1. Evolving Relationships
sections.text: In order to illustrate the performance of IAAs in dealing with evolving relationships between users, we assume the existence of a user who has just started at a new company. β β uses IAAs to interact with his work colleagues, represented as context Cwork = {β, γ, δ}, by an OSN. Initially, no message was exchanged between them. Consequently, all individual adequacy values are set to 0.5 (i.e. messages about tasks, meetings, etc.) Similarly, the adequacy lists are empty (i.e., messages about sports: Ac = ∅). From that moment on, several messages containing the work topic (i.e. messages about tasks, meetings, etc.) are exchanged between colleagues. Thus, the work topic is considered appropriate by all users (i.e., the information about sports: Ac: aworkc).1), while the rest of the topics are considered inappropriate.

sections.heading: 6. Evaluation
sections.text: In order to analyze the workings of IAAs and confirm our hypothesis about their behavior, in this section we analyze the characteristics of IAAs in terms of: contextual integrity preservation, exchange of standards, notification to their users, effects of environmental parameters, and robustness to malicious users. To this end, we conducted a series of experiments that illustrated the behavior of IAAs under a variety of different situations and conditions, scenarios with real OSN properties (e.g. scale-free networks, few strong bonds, etc.) and modeled heterogeneous users with different settings and preferences.

sections.text: As they receive information from others, they acquire new information that can also be exchanged. Parameters and their default values (which vary according to the experiment) are described in Table 1. Each user on the OSN has been implemented as a user agent. There is a group of 100 user agents between whom friendship relationships are randomly built according to a scale-free pattern, according to empirical studies that show that OSNs are scale-free [49]. In our scenario, we assume that users can only share information with their friends (as is the case with Facebook and other established OSN), and a subset of these friendship relationships is randomly selected to establish close and trustworthy friendshipment.8 Users are grouped to form contexts or communities. sections.heading: 6.2.1. Contextual Integrity Maintenance
sections.text: In our first experiment, we tried to determine whether IAAs contribute to maintaining contextual integrity, that is, whether IAAs contribute to reducing the exchange of inappropriate information and the dissemination of sensitive information. To this end, we simulated societies populated with compliant users (who know and follow the standards), each simulation running during 2000 and repeated 100 times to support the results, calculating for each execution the messages exchanging inappropriate information and disseminating the messages disseminating sensitive information. We also repeated this experiment by increasing the proportion of compliant users (who know and follow the standards).

sections.heading: 6.2.2. Information Sharing Norm Learning
sections.text: In the previous experiment, we showed that IAAs maintain contextual integrity when the network is formed between compliant users (who know and comply with the standards) and obedient users (who try to learn and comply with the standards).A more complex scenario arises when IAAs deal with societies where there are users who do not care about the standards for information exchange (i.e., random users).In this situation, it is more difficult to derive the standards based on the information exchanged, as random users share appropriate and inappropriate information indistinctly. To assess the extent to which IAAs are able to learn the standards for information exchange in these types of situations, we conducted an experiment in which we increased the percentage of compliant users in each context from 0% to 90%.

sections.heading: 6.2.3. Alerts Raised
sections.text: This experiment aims to evaluate the performance of IAAs in terms of the number of alerts raised and how many of these alerts are not followed by users. To this end, we have conducted simulations equipped with compliant users and relationship-based users (who do not follow the recommendations of IAAs when exchanging information with close and trusted friends); we have set the percentage of compliant users in each context to 40% to model existing standards for information exchange; and we have increased the number of steps required in the simulation to determine standards for information exchange and for close and trusting relationships to avoid alarms when information exchange violations are declared because recipients are close or trustworthy friends; these alerts may be considered unnecessary and disruptive as users are unlikely to follow them. Figure 6 shows that the percentage of alarms raising alarms and the percentage of relationships not following the number of alarms falling to 25% due to the number of alarms not following the low steps.

sections.heading: 6.2.4. Simulation Parameters
sections.text: In the previous experiments, we set the maximum number of topics discussed in a message, and the maximum quota of inappropriate topics and sensitive associations. To analyze the influence of these parameters on the performance of IAAs, we conducted two experiments in which we set the percentage of compatible users in each message to 40% of messages to share information already generated, and the rest of the users in each context are obedient users of messages. We repeated these two experiments by using random users instead of obedient users in each message as base simulation of messages. Each simulation was performed in 2000 steps and repeated 100 time periods. The composition of our previous experiments wanted to evaluate the performance of IAAs in a general situation, i.e. when users are allowed to select any number of topics discussed in a message. sections.heading: 6.2.5. Robustness against Malicious Users
sections.text: This experiment aims to analyze the performance of IAAs in the presence of malicious users; i.e. attackers who intend to inject fake messages to increase the appropriateness of a topic. Malicious users exchanged messages that contained malicious information (i.e. information related to an inappropriate topic targeted by malicious users). Specifically, we set the percentage of obedient users in each context to 10%, and we varied the malicious user ratio from 0% to 90%. The rest of the users in each context were compliant users. We repeated this experiment with random users instead of obedient users as a base simulation. Each simulation was performed in 2000 steps and repeated 100 times.Figure 11 shows the behavior of random users and obedient users in relation to the exchange of inappropriate information. The average percentage of messages sent by malicious users decreases if the amount of inappropriate user information is congested.

sections.heading: 6.2.6. Realistic User Populations
sections.text: Previous experiments have been aimed at assessing the characteristics of IAAs in terms of some specific criteria, which is why we have created societies with an extreme distribution of user types. However, these settings may not seem realistic; for example, a situation in which all users do not care about the standards is unlikely. In contrast, this section represents a more realistic simulation in which the distribution of different types of users coincides with the results of empirical studies on privacy concerns among the general public [72, 44]. Specifically, and according to [72], we have defined the ratio of obedient and compatible users (i.e., norm fundamentalists) as 26% - of which 15% are compatible users to model the emergence of norms and the rest are obedient users; the ratio of relationship-based users (i.e. norm pragmatists) as 64%, and the ratio of random users to compatible users (i.e. norms that are not compatible) as normal.

sections.heading: 7. Related Work
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 7.1. Contextual Integrity Modelling and Reasoning
sections.text: Previous work on computer models of contextual integrity suggested mechanisms for modelling and arguing the principles of contextual integrity. Thus, Barth et al. [4] formalized some aspects of contextual integrity on the assumption that there are a set of explicitly defined norms that determine what is allowed and what is prohibited, that interactions take place in well-known contexts and that interaction participants play a specific role in each interaction. In a recent paper, Krupa et al. [43] proposed a framework for enforcing norms for information exchange in an electronic institution in which norms, contexts and roles are explicitly defined. While these approaches seem appropriate for the type of domains described in [4] and [43], OSNs do not provide well-known contexts, but no explicit definition of the roles played by users, and information exchange is governed by implicit norms of information exchange.

sections.heading: 7.2. Access Control Models for OSNs
sections.text: These new paradigms range from cryptographic data protection systems used to define and implement group access policies [2, 36, 46, 75] to relationship-based access control models [27, 29, 28, 8, 14, 13, 16] that use a variety of features or aspects to characterize users "relationships and define access control decisions based on them. While these new models represent better frameworks than other traditional access control approaches to develop tools for defining and enforcing access control policies in OSNs, it is unlikely that access control alone will be the complete and definitive solution for adequate data protection management in OSNs, since users need an awareness of access control decisions to fully understand the consequences of their access control policies. [41, 50] These access control models, on the other hand, are implicitly designed to prevent information from being implied.

sections.heading: 7.3. Disclosure Decision-Making Mechanisms
sections.text: In related literature, however, the use of software equipped with disclosure decision-making mechanisms is not new. Thus, several authors [76, 42] have proposed mechanisms for calculating the privacy benefit-trade-off between disclosure of information in online interactions. However, these mechanisms have difficulties in dealing with scenarios in which the direct benefit of disclosure of information is a priori unknown or economically difficult to express, such as in OSNs, where disclosure is largely driven by social factors. [38] In a recent paper, Such et al. [71] have proposed a mechanism to equip agents with skills to select the personal attributes of their users that are to be disclosed to other agents during interactions, with the increase in intimacy and data losses that disclosure may cause, but that this mechanism is ultimately not considered by the IAEA.

sections.heading: 7.4. Topic Analysis
sections.text: Our proposal is based on the existence of a mechanism capable of determining the topics discussed by the information exchanged in OSNs (i.e. messages). Topics may be categories predefined by the underlying OSN infrastructure [54]; user-generated tags such as Flickr categories [53]; or categories or tags extracted from images [66, 80], videos [3], geolocation information [45], or text [57, 74, 12]. A common problem with user-generated tags is that tagging terms are often ambiguous, overpersonalized, and inaccurate [37]. In fact, current OSNs offer little or no synonym (i.e., other words, the same meaning) or homonym (i.e., the same word, different meanings) control [33, 48]. To overcome these problems, recent advances in the field of information science have mechanisms for clustering semantically related (i.e., the tags are referred to as in our paper).

sections.heading: 7.5. Norm Learning
sections.text: Standardized learning [23] is the process of learning how to behave in a given situation. In the case of ONS, norms for information exchange are implicit (i.e. there is no explicit definition of what is sensitive or inappropriate), and supervised machine learning algorithms cannot be used to derive norms for information exchange. In the existing literature, social learning [17] is defined as the process of deriving implicit social norms simultaneously through repeated interactions with members of the social network. In most proposals for social learning, norms are derived by analyzing the results of interactions and normative decisions for the benefit. [65] As mentioned above, the benefits of information exchange can be difficult to determine in economic terms. In other proposals, norms are derived by analyzing explicit normative signals such as penalties, sanctions and rewards.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed the first calculation model for the implicit contextual integrity in OSNs. However, this model considers that in OSNs contexts are implicit, a priori unknown, and can change; user relationships evolve; and standards for information exchange are implicit, i.e., they define the behavior that is consistent with the most common behavior; this model of implicit contextual integrity includes an information exchange model that is in force in OSNs, and an information wizard model that is intended to help users avoid the exchange of inappropriate information and the dissemination of sensitive information via ONSs. Experiments we conducted show that: (i) IAAs are able to derive standards for information exchange, even if a small percentage of users follow the standards and in the presence of malicious users; (ii) IAAs help to reduce the exchange of inappropriate information and the dissemination of sensitive information that is transmitted by the users, and the situation of the system that is not transmitted by the users.

Norm learning [23] is the process of learning how to behave in a specific situation.
In the existing literature, social learning [17] of norms is defined as the process of inferring implicit social norms concurrently over repeated interactions with members of the social network.
In most of the proposals on social learning, norms are inferred by analysing the outcomes of interactions and normative decisions in terms of utility [65].
In other proposals, norms are inferred by analysing explicit normative signals such as punishments, sanctions and rewards [77].
Other approaches [23], use imitation as a mechanism for learning social norms.

metadata.abstractText: Many real incidents demonstrate that users of Online Social Networks need mechanisms that help them manage their interactions by increasing the awareness of the different contexts that coexist in Online Social Networks and preventing them from exchanging inappropriate information in those contexts or disseminating sensitive information from some contexts to others. Contextual integrity is a privacy theory that conceptualises the appropriateness of information sharing based on the contexts in which this information is to be shared. Computational models of Contextual Integrity assume the existence of well-defined contexts, in which individuals enact pre-defined roles and information sharing is governed by an explicit set of norms. However, contexts in Online Social Networks are known to be implicit, unknown a priori and ever changing; users relationships are constantly evolving; and the information sharing norms are implicit. This makes current Contextual Integrity models not suitable for Online Social Networks. In this paper, we propose the first computational model of Implicit Contextual Integrity, presenting an information model for Implicit Contextual Integrity as well as a so-called Information Assistant Agent that uses the information model to learn implicit contexts, relationships and the information sharing norms in order to help users avoid inappropriate information exchanges and undesired information disseminations. Through an experimental evaluation, we validate the properties of the model proposed. In particular, Information Assistant Agents are shown to: (i) infer the information sharing norms even if a small proportion of the users follow the norms and in presence of malicious users; (ii) help reduce the exchange of inappropriate information and the dissemination of sensitive information with only a partial view of the system and the information received and sent by their users; and (iii) minimise the burden to the users in terms of raising unnecessary alerts.
